items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 5.03 mAOD at 16:45 on 22/10/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 175 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the nextÂ 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely.  River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street.  The forecast is for dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23 October.

items.description: Middle River Roding
items.message:
The middle River Roding has continued to rise slowly overnight in Abridge and Loughton and remains high and out of banks in response to heavy rain yesterday. 
River levels are starting to peak and level off and we do not expect flooding to properties. River levels will remain high and out of banks today, Friday 22 October. Flooding of low lying land, roads and gardens close to the river around Abridge and Loughton is expected. 
Flooding from surface water could also occur. 
Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 30 cm of fast-flowing water can move a car and 6 inches can knock an adult off their feet.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are continuing to monitor river levels and will update this message this evening.

items.message:
The water level in Sherbourne Lake is stable but remains above the flood alert threshold as a result of heavy rainfall on Wednesday evening. This may cause some localised flooding of land in the immediate area throughout today, 22/10/21. However, the River Yeo at Pen Mill, the River Wriggle at Chetnole and the River Cam at Weston Bampfylde have all fallen to normal winter levels with no flood risk.
Dry weather is forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect the Sherbourne Lake level to slowly fall. We will continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response teams continue their checks on flood defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded, refer to local authority website for local road closures and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday, 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is still high between Midhurst and Fittleworth, following Wednesday's rain. Throughout Friday 22/10/2021 flooding will continue to affect isolated properties between Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth, as well as there being extensive water in fields and gardens and affecting rural roads. The river is now slowly falling along the length of the Western Rother, so flood impacts should slowly ease. However, a significant improvement is unlikely before Saturday 23/10/2021. The weather forecast is for predominantly dry days until Tuesday, but with the possibility of showers Sunday and Monday. This dry weather should allow the river to continue to fall, however at Fittleworth flows will remain higher than normal until the middle of next week. In Liss, Sheet, Iping, Stedham, Midhurst and communities on the Lod, river flows are already near normal. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 22/10/2021.

High tide at Cowes is forecast in the early hours of Friday morning at 00:27 on 22/10/21. For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the river will remain a little elevated, but overall the situation will improve and garden flooding in Marsh Road is not expected. Over the next few days, the weather is forecast to remain dry and tide levels are also reducing. No further impacts are currently expected.

No further flooding to low lying land and roads is expected.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water levels in the Eastern Yar are beginning to fall from very high levels earlier in the week. This was following 55mm of rain recorded at Knighton on Wednesday (20/10/21). Currently, the river is still very high at Sandown but falling in Alverstone. Field flooding is expected along the Yar Valley. Golf Links Road will be flooded and today (22/10/21) minor impact flooding may continue to affect Moreton Common Road. Land around holiday parks in Sandown may be flooded, as water will struggle to drain to the river. Property flooding is not expected. Over the next few days, the weather will be settled and dry. In Alverstone, the river is now dropping back to normal levels and will continue to do so this afternoon. In Sandown, the river peaked around midnight (21/10/21) and is now stable and will begin to fall slowly this afternoon. During the daytime (22/10/21) it will continue to be bank full at Sandown Road Bridge. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This flood alert will be updated or removed by 10:00 on Saturday 23/10/21.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is still high near Barcombe, following Wednesday's heavy rain. Through Friday 22/10/2021, minor flooding will continue to affect the Anchor Inn, Anchor Lane and Barcombe Mills Road, as well as water extensively through fields near Barcombe particularly. However, even in Barcombe, river levels have already fallen from Thursday's peak. The weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Flooding impacts should ease on the Ouse by Saturday 23/10/2021. River flows near Ardingly, Lindfield, Sloop Lane and Fletching have already fallen to near normal. Some roads mentioned in this message may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 22/10/2021.

items.description: Upper Arun
items.message: The River Arun is still high between Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pallingham Lock, following Wednesdayâs rain. However, water levels seem to have now peaked, or are already falling, and the weather forecast is for predominantly dry days until Sunday. Minor residual flood impacts including water in fields and on roads and near isolated riverside buildings will now slowly ease. However these flood impacts are likely to remain until at least Saturday near Pallingham Lock. The river flow through Horsham, Broadbridge Heath and Wanford has already returned to near normal. It will take until next week before normal flows are returned at Pallingham Lock. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while residual flood impacts remain. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 21:00 22/10/2021.

items.description: Lower Arun
items.message: The River Arun is still high and rising following Wednesday's heavy rain. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Flood water will affect the A29 at Pulborough and will be extensive through nearby fields. For four hours from 12:00 22/10/2021 water will be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. We are not currently expecting flooding to affect Arundel or Ford. The weather forecast is for five predominantly dry days, with the exception of possible showers Sunday and Monday. Despite this, river levels at Pulborough and Greatham Bridge are expected to continue slowly rising until the early hours of Saturday morning 23/10/2021. And river flows will remain much higher than normal for most of next week. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 21:00 22/10/2021.

The next tide will peak at Trowlock Island on 23/10/21 at 04:15 and will be 4.951m, therefore an alert will not be issued for this tide later today unless the situation changes, and we will continue to closely monitor this.

items.description: River Blackwater
items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater remains high, but it is now slowly falling. In the last 48 hours, close to half a monthâs rain (43mm) was recorded in Romsey. For the rest of the day, the river will remain very high around the mill building and water will be ponded on low lying roads, land and fields, especially at West Wellow. Over the next few days, the weather is forecast to remain dry. It will take another 8 hours before the water level reduces significantly, and it will be several days before the river returns to normal. Given the more settled outlook, no further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is still high, following Wednesday's rain. However, the river is now slowly falling and the weather is forecast to remain predominantly dry for the next couple of days. Minor flood impacts will likely continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and possibly land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park, but extents and depths of water should gradually ease as the river falls through Shripney, Bersted and Aldingbourne. The lowering of water levels will be slow and the Aldingbourne Rife will remain higher than normal until next week. No flood impacts are expected in Barnham, where river levels have fallen a lot quicker, and are already close to normal flow. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. Our pumps at Felpham are running, and we will keep grilles clear through Barnham, including at the Trading Post, to reduce flood risk. We will reissue this message if the flood risk to properties increases again.

items.description: Middle River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday but are beginning to fall. The risk of flooding of roads and low lying land remains high for today, 22/10/2021. Flooding is expected to continue to affect Tonbridge playing fields, town centre car parks and low lying land and roads from Tonbridge through Tudeley and East Peckham. This is likely to include the sports pitches, also known as the racecourse, and Postern Lane in Tonbridge. Flooding of properties is not expected. No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until this afternoon, 22/10/2021. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation. Please avoid walking in, or driving through, floodwater. This message will be updated this evening, 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox
items.message: The River Lox is still high following Wednesday's rain, but river levels have been slowly falling overnight. Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens during Friday, but the weather forecast is for five predominantly dry days which will allow river levels to fall and flood impacts to ease further. It might take until Saturday for river flows to return to near normal. Please continue to operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Lower Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high following Wednesday's wet weather, when more than half a month's rain (55mm) was recorded at Ardingly. Tide levels at Newhaven on Friday are predicted to peak almost 20cm lower than Thursday. Which means water levels along the lower Ouse on Thursday evening, and on Friday, should not exceed heights we have recently seen. Minor flood impacts could still affect fields, rural roads, and gardens in Hamsey, the Malling Deanery and Pells areas of Lewes and near Piddinghoe Church. Impacts will reduce over the next few days. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday and Monday. Flood risk is not expected to return until another spell of persistently wet weather occurs. Please continue to plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.description: Barcombe Mills
items.message: The River Ouse is still high near Barcombe, following Wednesday's heavy rainfall. However, water levels have fallen from Thursday's peak. Minor flooding will continue to affect the Anchor Inn, Anchor Lane and Barcombe Mills Road until Friday evening. A flood alert remains in force to communicate these impacts, and the extensive water through nearby fields that will continue until the weekend. However, the weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. No new property flooding is expected in Barcombe so we are removing this flood warning. Some roads may be affected by flood water, including those mentioned within this message. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will reissue this flood warning if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from today, Friday 22 October, and for the rest of the day.  High water levels may remain into the weekend, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.    Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23 October.

items.description: Danes Stream
items.message: The water level in the Danes Stream remains very high, but it is now slowly falling. In the last 24 hours, more than half a monthâs rain (50 mm) has been recorded at Stem Lane. Over the last few hours, the river has been high enough to impact footpaths through Milford on Sea. Over the next few days, the weather is forecast to remain dry. It will take another 8 hours before the water level reduces significantly, but hour on hour the situation should continue to improve. It will be several days before the river returns to normal. Given the more settled outlook and reducing tide heights, no further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.10 m and is stable. 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
Pumping is not currently taking place at Huish Episcopi pumping station. Dry weather is forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to slowly decrease as a result.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday, 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely.  River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet.  The forecast is for light rainfall during the day and into this evening. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23 October.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message: River levels are high and rising at the Stinsford river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall.  The next couple of days are forecast to be dry but we do expect further rainfall over the weekend.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.  River levels can rise very quickly in response to rainfall.  Our incident response staff are in contact with community flood wardens and volunteers.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 11.00 AM on Friday 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from East Stoke to Wareham
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been issued due to last night's heavy rainfall. Levels on the Lower Frome quite quickly and are expected to peak at East Stoke  later tonight. 
Places most at risk include areas in East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham.
River levels are expected to remain high overnight and flooding of properties will continue.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Consider activating any property flood protection products .
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.
Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so.

items.description: Tidal River Crane

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
River levels on the Crane remain high but are dropping  following heavy rainfall across the catchment yesterday. 
A high tide is expected at Richmond on Thames at around 4pm on Friday 22 October. Due to high flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates will not be able to close to hold back the incoming tide from the River Thames. 
As a result, the incoming tide will flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the flow already in the channel, will push levels very high. Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is possible, from around 3:30pm although we do not expect any flooding to buildings. Any flooding is likely to be of short duration covering the period around high tide.
It is forecast to stay mostly dry today and river levels on the Crane will continue to fall throughout the day. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river. Be aware of your surroundings and keep an eye on local conditions.
This message will be updated after the next high tide this afternoon.

items.description: Pulborough on the River Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high and rising. Over half a month's rainfall (65mm) was recorded on Wednesday. From 11:00 Friday 22/10/2021, flooding will affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Flood water will also affect the A29 at Pulborough, and will be extensive through nearby fields and gardens. The weather outlook is for predominantly dry days until Sunday 24/10/2021, however despite this, the River Arun will continue to slowly rise in Pulborough until the early hours of Saturday 23/10/2021. River levels could peak at a similar height as experienced in February 2020. A week of dry weather will be required before flows return to normal. Some roads included in this message may become impassable, as a precaution please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, such as the A29 to Pulborough. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 17:00 Friday 22/10/2021.
